entry.title: Review: Small life enhancements come with Apple Watch
entry.summary: NEW YORK (AP) " Apple Watch isn't so much a lifestyle revolution as it is a collection of small enhancements that add up.

entry.title: Review: Small life enhancements come with Apple Watch
entry.summary:
With Apple Pay on iPhones, I'm able to leave my wallet in my pocket to pay at several chains, including McDonald's and Whole Foods.

While fitness trackers typically focus on counting steps, Apple Watch tracks calories burned and minutes of exercise.

Offsetting the health benefits: I can use the Remote app to control video on Apple TV instead of getting up to grab the physical remote.

entry.title: Review: Small life enhancements come with Apple Watch
entry.summary: Apple's smartwatch has a wider range of apps than rival watches from Samsung, Motorola and others.

entry.title: GE ties up with Qualcomm, Apple in new lighting business bet
entry.summary: (Reuters) - General Electric Co on Monday announced collaborations with Qualcomm Inc and Apple Inc as it uses digital technology and the growing appetite for data to reinvigorate its 130-year-old lighting business.

entry.title: Inked and irked: Apple Watch users report tattoo problems
entry.summary: That was frustrating and "a bit embarrassing" for Graham Edgell, a Los Angeles printing broker who loves Apple products and was eager to show off his new watch to friends after his wife bought it for him.

entry.title: Inked and irked: Apple Watch users report tattoo problems
entry.summary: As for the Apple Watch issue, some social media users have mocked it as a complaint from spoiled hipsters.

entry.title: Inked and irked: Apple Watch users report tattoo problems
entry.summary: That was a relief for Nick Borelli, a 34-year-old marketing executive in Cleveland who has a black tattoo on the inside of his wrist - not the side where he has worn the Apple Watch.

entry.title: Inked and irked: Apple Watch users report tattoo problems
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - It's an annoying problem for the unlucky few: the Apple Watch's heart rate monitor might not work if you have a tattoo on your wrist.

Inked and irked Apple fans have dubbed the issue "TattooGate" on Twitter, complaining that they must choose between their body art and their stylish gadget.

While the issue might sound like one of those "1 percenter problems" some Twitter users wondered how it happened that Apple didn't have a single designer or tester with a wrist tattoo who would have noticed the problem.

Apple suggests that users who can't get a consistent heart rate reading connect their Apple Watch wirelessly to external heart rate monitors.

Even so, "Antennagate" didn't seem to make a dent in the iPhone's popularity or sour Apple's devoted fan base, and it's unlikely that "TattooGate" will make or break the Apple Watch.

entry.title: Liking Apple too much a big problem for fund managers
entry.summary:
David Chiueh, the manager of the Upright Growth fund, has 13.4% in Apple, the second-largest among diversified funds tracked by Lipper, mostly because shares he bought in 2008 have appreciated, he said.

Mark Mulholland, whose Matthew 25 fund is classified as a non-diversified fund, has 15.3% of his portfolio's assets in Apple.

Yet that devotion for Apple is a problem for Burnham and some other managers of so-called diversified funds like his - they want more Apple than they can buy under self-imposed risk-reducing guidelines that typically have them holding no more than 5% of their assets in any one company.

NEW YORK - At more than 15% of his fund's assets, John Burnham, manager of the US$136 million Burnham Fund, has a larger stake in Apple Inc than any other diversified fund.

entry.title: Dark tattoos daunt Apple Watch
entry.summary: 'Permanent or temporary changes to your skin, such as some tattoos, can also impact heart rate sensor performance,' Apple said.

entry.title: Apple Watch delivery slowed by faulty part, report says
entry.summary: Shipments of the highly anticipated Apple Watch are reportedly being slowed by a faulty component manufactured by one of Apple's suppliers in China.

entry.summary: A member of Russia's parliament has asked prosecutors to determine whether Apple violated Russia's ban on gay "propaganda" when it delivered U2's latest album to a half-billion iTunes users for free last year.

entry.title: Apple Watch may not work properly if you have a tattoo
entry.summary: A spokesman for Apple in Sydney declined to comment on Thursday, but three Apple employees at its flagship Sydney store, including a senior advisor from its tech support line, said they were unaware of any issue.

entry.title: Apple, IBM Partner with Japan Post for Elderly Care

entry.title: Apple, IBM announce partnership with Japan Post to improve elderly care

entry.title: Apple, IBM, Japan Post team up to improve elderly care

entry.title: Apple, IBM, Japan Post team up to improve elderly care

entry.title: Tattoos disrupt key Apple Watch functions
entry.summary:
Early adopters of the Apple Watch, Apple Inc.'s first new product in five years, are complaining that a number of its key functions are disrupted by their tattoos.

entry.title: Apple Watch sensors confused by ... tattoos?
Tattoo snafu irks inked Apple Watch wearers
entry.summary:
An Apple support article says the watch uses green LED lights paired with light-sensitive photodiodes to detect the amount of blood flowing through the wrist and calculate the frequency of heart beats.

"We have been hearing suppliers encountering some bottleneck issues for Apple Watch's production such as problems with its displays, haptics or assembly," he told Reuters, adding that those issues were quite common for new products.

entry.title: Defective component slowed Apple Watch rollout: report
entry.summary:
Apple has not given any sales figures for its hotly anticipated Apple Watch since it began taking orders this month.

As a result, Apple is now sourcing nearly all of its components from the other supplier, Japan's Nidec Corp. It may take time for the company to increase production, the people told the Journal.

entry.title: Microsoft opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android apps
entry.summary: Microsoft is releasing new programming tools for Azure clients to create programs for computers that run Apple and Linux software, as well as those that run Windows.

entry.title: Microsoft Opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android Apps
entry.summary: Microsoft's move to help developers adapt their Apple and Android apps for Windows 10 is a major change from the past, when each company maintained rigid differences in their software platforms.

entry.title: Microsoft opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android apps
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Microsoft hopes to get more people using the next version of its Windows software on all kinds of devices, by giving them access to many of the same apps they're already using on Apple or Android phones.

Today, after losing ground to smartphones and tablets that run software from rivals Apple and Google, Microsoft wants to make Windows 10 the universal software for PCs, phones and other Internet-connected gadgets.

Currently, there are more than 1.4 million apps for Android phones and about the same for Apple devices, while there are only a few hundred thousand apps that work on Windows phones and tablets.

entry.title: Microsoft opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android apps

entry.title: Discover discovers Apple Pay for its US cardholders
entry.summary: With Apple Pay, credit card numbers are not stored on the device or on Apple servers.

entry.title: Discover discovers Apple Pay for its US cardholders
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - U.S. users of Discover cards are getting their Apple Pay, the last holdout among major credit card networks in the country.

Discover customers will also be able to use Apple Pay with iPad Air 2 and iPad mini 3 when paying for goods and services within apps starting in the fall.

entry.title: Low-key launch as Apple Watch finally goes on sale
entry.summary: "I buy one or two Apple products every time they release something new," Chiu Long, a 40-year-old IT worker from Taiwan, told Reuters while queuing up at Bic Camera.

entry.title: Low-key launch as Apple Watch finally goes on sale
entry.summary:
The company is directing people to order online instead, which should prevent the lines of Apple devotees who typically flock to iPhone and iPad launches.

About 50 people lined up to buy the watch at electronic store Bic Camera in Tokyo's Ginza district, while at the nearby Apple Store it was like any other Friday, according to Reuters reporters at the shops.

entry.title: Fashion stores to sell apple watch
entry.summary: Apple retail chief Angela Ahrendts has previously stated the selling process would be different for the watch than the huge queues normally seen outside the company's store for other products.

entry.title: Apple Watch goes on sale worldwide amid supply shortage
entry.summary: Apple has not released any numbers since it opened for pre-orders on April 10, but many buyers were told their watches would not arrive for a month or more as supply appeared to dry up.

entry.summary: "Our team is working to fill orders as quickly as possible based on the available supply and the order in which they were received," Apple said in a statement.

entry.title: Apple tests smartwatch market with quiet debut of Cook's first product
entry.summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) - The Apple Watch will launch with a whisper rather than a bang on Friday, an unusual start for the company that may reflect early uncertainty about demand for Apple Inc boss Tim Cook's first new product.

entry.title: Apple tests smartwatch market with quiet debut of Cook's first product
entry.summary: Apple will likely use preorders to perfect the consumer experience by giving watch customers more attention in stores and adding apps in time for the holiday season, said Shannon Cross, analyst at Cross Research.

entry.title: Apple tests smartwatch market with quiet debut of Cook's first product
entry.summary: In fact, the only watches on sale on Friday will be at a handful of upscale boutiques and department stores that Apple courted to help position the watch as a fashion item.

entry.title: Some Apple Watches shipping sooner than expected
entry.summary: Many who ordered the new smartwatch online earlier this month were told that delivery could take a month or longer, although Apple has promised to begin deliveries Friday to those who were among the first to place orders.

entry.title: Some Apple Watches shipping sooner than expected
entry.summary: But Apple Inc. is now contacting some customers who were originally told to expect a lengthy wait time and letting them know their watches could arrive sooner.

entry.title: Some Apple Watches to come sooner than expected
entry.summary: In a note to clients on Wednesday, FDR analyst Daniel Ives estimated Apple would take over 2 million pre-orders for the watch and ship 20 million of them in 2015.

entry.title: IBM joins with Apple, J&J in health data venture
entry.summary:
International Business Machines, deepening its partnership with Apple to make use of health information gathered by millions of Apple devices, is creating a unit dedicated to providing data analytics to the healthcare sector.

IBM already has an arrangement to work with Apple on numerous enterprise applications, but is extending its co-operation in the area of health.

entry.title: Apple Watch US pre-orders estimated at 1M
entry.summary:
Apple's first foray into the world of the smartwatch generated nearly 1 million pre-orders in the United States on Friday, according to early estimates by the research firm Slice Intelligence.

Using e-receipt data, the company said that 957,000 people in the U.S. placed orders for an Apple Watch on the first day it became available.

Apple touted the design of the Watch at its launch in March and the devices have a number of interchangeable bands.

In an attempt to create exclusivity and capture a high-end, luxury audience, Apple has even released an 18-karat gold version known as the Edition which starts at $10,000.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Shopping begins
entry.summary:
Employees of the Lenox Square Mall's Apple store in Atlanta clapped and cheered as customers streamed through its glass doors just before 10 a.m. About 20 people had lined up outside the second-floor storefront.

Inside the store, Apple retail workers could be seen through the glass doors setting up displays, including a line of glass-topped cases containing the new watches.

entry.title: Why Apple is likely to boost watch production soon
entry.summary:
Apple is likely to quickly ramp production of the Apple Watch after strong pre-orders outstripped limited supply in the first weekend following its launch, some Wall Street analysts said.

The company will sell the gadgets in Apple stores and online as well as in trendy fashion boutiques in Paris, London and Tokyo as part of a strategy to position the wearable computer as a must-have accessory.

Apple is widely expected to disclose weekend pre-order numbers at around 8:30 a.m. ET on Monday.

entry.summary: - Trader Joe's customers who bought the chain's Sweet Apple Chicken Sausage are urged to throw it out amid concerns plastic may have made its way into the packages.

entry.summary: The analysts said their checks showed that Apple appeared to be ordering components for the watch that would allow it to build well over 20 million watches this year.

entry.title: Online excitement but no long lines for Apple Watch debut
entry.summary: In this photo taken with a fisheye lens, customers listen as an Apple employee points toward Apple's new watch, in San Francisco, Friday, April 10, 2015.

entry.title: Swiss launch of Apple Watch hit by patent issue
entry.summary:
ZURICH - Apple is not able to launch its new smartwatch in Switzerland until at least the end of this year because of an intellectual property rights issue, Swiss broadcaster RTS reported on its website.

The Apple Watch, the firm's first new device since Tim Cook became CEO, will be available in stores in nine countries on April 24.

entry.title: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade, claim Edward Snowden papers
entry.summary:
It said the latest documents, which covered a period from 2006 to 2013, stop short of proving whether U.S. intelligence researchers had succeeded in breaking Apple's encryption coding, which secures user data and communications.

Efforts to break into Apple products by government security researchers started as early as 2006, a year before Apple introduced its first iPhone and continued through the launch of the iPad in 2010 and beyond, The Intercept said.

The report says top-secret documents reveal U.S. government researchers had created a version of XCode, Apple's software application development tool, to create surveillance backdoors.

entry.title: An apple a day might keep the pharmacist away: study
entry.summary:
Limitations of the study include its reliance on self-reports of apple consumption, doctor visits and prescriptions.

An apple a day might not keep the doctor away, but it might help keep the pharmacist at bay, a new study suggests.

entry.title: Apple trying to entice musicians?including Taylor Swift into deals for Beats streaming
entry.summary:
Apple has also approached Taylor Swift and others about partnerships, the report said.

Apple bought audio equipment and music streaming company Beats for about $3 billion in May 2014, hoping to catch up in fast-growing music streaming industry.

entry.title: Your guide to trying on, ordering Apple Watch
entry.summary: The smartwatch is Apple's first new product category in five years and comes in 54 configurations - more than any other Apple gadget.

entry.title: The last days of Steve Jobs: New biography reveals how ailing Apple CEO invited his successor Tim Cook to watch a sappy football film on the eve of his death and how Bill Gates paid one final visit to talk shop
entry.summary:
Apple CEO Tim Cook still remembers the last movie he ever saw with Steve Jobs before he succumbed to cancer: the sentimental football flick Remember the Titans.

Six days after Cook and Jobs' movie night, the co-founder of Apple passed away at his Palo Alto, California, estate from complications related to pancreatic cancer.

entry.title: Apple to replace AT&T on Dow Jones
entry.summary: "As the largest corporation in the world and a leader in technology, Apple is the clear choice for the Dow Jones Industrial Average," said David Blitzer, chairman of the Index Committee at S&P Dow Jones Indices.

entry.title: EU regulators probe Apple's music streaming plans in Europe: FT
entry.summary: The commission has sought details from several music labels and digital streaming companies on their agreements with Apple, as the iPhone maker gears up to launch its own music streaming service this summer, the report said.

entry.summary: Apple is in talks to launch an online TV service, the Wall Street Journal reported late Monday, citing sources familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Court monitor: Apple antitrust cooperation has 'declined'
entry.summary: Bromwich said Apple was making progress before significant setbacks arose since October.

entry.title: Court Monitor: Apple Antitrust Cooperation Has 'Declined'
entry.summary: Since then, he said, "Apple's communications with us reverted to the more adversarial tone taken in the first few months of the monitorship, including attempts to prescribe and limit how the monitor should conduct his reviews and write his reports."

entry.title: Court-appointed monitor says Apple's antitrust cooperation 'sharply declined' in recent months
entry.summary: NEW YORK - A court-appointed monitor says Apple Inc.'s cooperation with efforts in a New York federal case to improve its compliance with antitrust laws took on an "adversarial tone" recently.

entry.title: Court monitor: Apple antitrust cooperation has 'declined'
entry.summary:
Bromwich was appointed to review the Cupertino, California company's antitrust compliance policies and training after the judge concluded in a case in New York that Apple violated antitrust laws when it entered the e-book market in 2010.

Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., an Apple attorney, told appeals judges in December that Seattle-based Amazon was the monopoly in the e-book market before Apple arrived on the scene.

entry.title: Court monitor: Apple antitrust cooperation has 'declined'
entry.summary:
He said Apple's cooperation with his team deteriorated as the company rejected requests to interview business personnel, refused to turn over certain documents and information and only let Bromwich's team look at a small sample of training sessions.

Apple's program still lacked an independent antitrust compliance officer and adequate board oversight, he said.

He said Apple has conducted interviews and distributed a survey to employees to collect feedback to improve its antitrust compliance program.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary: Apple won't necessarily buy paper made from trees on that land, but Jackson said the investment will increase the supply of sustainable wood fiber.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary: Apple is expanding its environmental efforts by investing in a new Chinese solar power project and preserving 36,000 acres of "sustainable" timberland in Maine and North Carolina.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary:
(AP) - In a quest to be more green, Apple says it is investing in Chinese solar power and preserving forests that make environmentally friendly paper.

It's also promising to use more renewable power overseas, where Apple relies heavily on contract manufacturers - and where a top executive acknowledged the company can do more.

By comparison, Apple is spending $850 million for rights to nearly half the output of a 280-megawatt solar facility planned for construction south of Apple's Cupertino, California, headquarters.

That project will produce enough energy to power all of Apple's California offices, a computer center and 52 retail stores.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary:
The new solar project in China has a capacity of 40 megawatts, which is smaller than some projects Apple has announced in the United States.

Still, the Chinese project will produce more than the amount of energy consumed by Apple's 19 corporate offices and 21 retail stores in China and Hong Kong, Jackson said.

entry.title: LA Unified asks Apple to end delivery of Pearson products
entry.summary: The Los Angeles Unified School District is telling Apple it's dissatisfied with the Pearson Education curriculum for student iPads and wants reimbursement for all the learning materials schools haven't been able to use.

entry.title: 6% of US adults plan to buy Apple Watch: Poll
entry.summary: "I already have the iPhone, the iPad, pretty much everything that Apple offers," said poll respondent Sefu Grady, a 37-year- old counselor living in Clinton, Mississippi.

entry.title: Exclusive: Six percent of U.S. adults plan to buy Apple Watch - Reuters/Ipsos poll
entry.summary:
The poll showed the watch, marketed by Apple as a high-fashion item as well as a new frontier in technology, appealed to fewer than 4 percent of women compared with 9 percent of men.

People around the world flocked to Apple stores on April 10 to try on the watches, which go on sale officially on April 24, and online orders quickly outstripped supply, with most customers facing at least a month's wait.

entry.title: Exclusive: Six percent of U.S. adults plan to buy Apple Watch - Reuters/Ipsos poll
entry.summary: According to the poll, adults aged between 30 and 39 were the most likely buyers, with 13 percent saying they planed to buy an Apple Watch, followed by 10 percent of 18-to-29-year-olds.

Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary:
One image, an outstretched hand with colorful designs flowing from a fingertip, was licensed from Craig & Karl by Apple.

In fact, when the Apple "Start Something New" campaign appeared, Britto received messages congratulating him, incorrectly, for what appeared to be a new business deal with Apple.

entry.title: Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary: After investigating the source of the Apple image, according to the lawsuit, Britto's lawyers noticed apparent similarities between Craig & Karl's work and that of Britto.

entry.title: Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary: Officials at Apple and Craig & Karl did not immediately respond Monday to emails seeking comment.

entry.title: Artist sues Apple, design firm for allegedly misusing his style in ads
entry.summary:
MIAMI -- Artist Romero Britto is suing Apple Inc. and a design firm in Miami federal court for allegedly misusing his colour-splashed images and distinctive style in marketing campaigns.

The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages from Cupertino, California-based Apple and the design duo Craig Redman of New York and Karl Maier of London, whose company is called Craig & Karl.

Apple's "Start Something New" marketing campaign was cited in the lawsuit as one recent example of misuse of Britto art.

entry.title: US STOCKS-Wall St flat with earnings eyed; Apple, Qualcomm lift Nasdaq
entry.summary: Gains on the Nasdaq outpaced the two other major Wall Street indexes, buoyed by gains in Qualcomm, up 1.6 percent at $70.28, and Apple, up 0.8 percent at $128.16.

entry.title: Apple likely to boost watch production quickly - analysts
entry.summary: Analysts widely expect the Apple Watch to outsell similar watches offered by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, Sony Corp and LG Electronics, which have attracted lukewarm interest from consumers.

entry.title: Apple likely to boost watch production quickly: analysts
entry.summary:
The Apple Watch, which allows users to check email, listen to music and make phone calls when paired with an iPhone, goes on sale officially on April 24.

Munster, who expects Apple to sell 2.3 million watches in the April-June quarter, expects Apple to ramp production between mid-May and June.

Despite mixed reviews, which praised the watch's styling but criticized its less-than-spectacular battery life and slow-loading apps, people flocked to Apple's stores to get a close-up look.

entry.title: Apple Watch US pre-orders estimated at 1M
entry.summary:
Slice Intelligence looked at sample data from 9,080 online shoppers, and said each Apple Watch buyer ordered an average of 1.3 watches and spent an average of $503.83 per device.

Slice Intelligence said that U.S. customers spent an average of $382.83 on the Apple Watch Sport and $707.04 on the Apple Watch.

entry.title: Review: Many choices, indecision with Apple Watch

NEW YORK (AP) - Of the 13 Apple Watch models I tried over two sessions, the one I liked most cost $15,000.

I didn't have good answers as my Apple Watch try-on visits started - at first modestly, with models that cost about the same as an iPhone.

I bypassed the appointments because Apple's media reps in Cupertino, California, had arranged my sessions.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch
entry.summary: Along with a host of Apple-designed apps, such as Maps, Mail, Siri and Apple Pay, watch owners will be able to download numerous apps developed by outside companies.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch

entry.title: Strong turnout, backlogs, as shoppers get to try Apple Watch
entry.summary: But soon after online preorders opened on Friday, Apple's website listed shipping times in June for some models of the watch and four to six weeks for others, raising questions about whether Apple underestimated demand for its newest product.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Shopping begins
entry.summary:
In past years, Apple fans have held festive overnight vigils outside the store and lined up on the sidewalk to be among the first to buy the latest models of iPhones and iPads.

Apple's store in the U.S. is citing delivery of June or "4-6 weeks" for most models, including large expensive luxury versions with leather bands.

The 48-year old plumber knew which Apple Watch he wanted - the large Sport version with a black band for $399 - but he came to an Apple store rather than order online so that staff could walk him through it.

China was among countries where the watch had its global debut Friday, reflecting the country's fast-growing status as one of Apple's most important markets.

entry.title: Apple Watch options: 54 combinations of case, band, size
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - Apple Watch comes with a choice of watch case, band and size - there are 54 possible configurations in all.

To help you choose, Apple has plenty of videos on its website and Apple Store and Apple Watch apps.

The Apple Store app also has sizing guides, images of the watch cases in actual size and animation of buckles and clasps, which you can open and close by pinching in and out.

NEW YORK (AP) - Buying an Apple Watch won't be as simple as walking into an Apple store and handing over your credit card.

So starting Friday, Apple stores will have staff trained to help you choose.

No smartwatch has gotten as much attention as the Apple Watch, given Apple's devoted fan base and the company's knack for designing products consumers can't live without.

Starting Friday, Apple Store staff will be able to help you choose from the array of options.

Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"After using it, I had no question that the Apple Watch is the most advanced piece of wearable technology you can buy today," Bloomberg's Josh Topolsky wrote.

But, he said, "the Apple Watch isn't quite the gatekeeper to my digital life that I wanted. Take app alerts -- there's a fine line between being in the know and having your wrist jiggle all day."

entry.title: Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary: But, according to New York Times tech columnist Farhad Manjoo, while he generally liked the Apple Watch after a "steep" learning curve, the third-party apps available for the device are "mostly useless right now."

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch-reviewers
entry.summary:
April 8 (Reuters) - Apple Inc's "beautiful" and "stylish" smartwatch could make life easier for people on the move, reviewers say, but the gadget gets poor marks for battery life and slow-loading apps.

Reviews published on Wednesday made much of the device's relatively poor battery life - up to 18 hours, according to Apple - and said its apps will need upgrades to load more quickly.

entry.title: Reviews are in: Apple Watch performs well but isn't a necessity
entry.summary: CNET: "The Apple Watch is the most ambitious, well-constructed smartwatch ever seen, but first-gen shortfalls make it feel more like a fashionable toy than a necessary tool."

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch: reviewers
entry.summary: But the software is "initially complex" and not suited to tech novices - unusual for an Apple device, said Farhad Manjoo, who reviewed the watch for the New York Times.

entry.title: Early Apple Watch reviews are mixed
entry.summary: Wall Street Journal: "After over a week of living with Apple's latest gadget on my wrist, I realized the company isn't just selling some wrist-worn computer, it's selling good looks and coolness, with some bonus computer features. Too many features that are too hard to find, if you ask me."

entry.title: Apple Watch pros and cons: What reviewers are saying
entry.summary:
Apple Inc's smartwatch is a "beautiful", "stylish" and "elegantly made" piece of technology that could make life easier for people on the move, reviewers said, but it also has shortcomings and a price that could limit its appeal.

"For now, the Apple Watch is for pioneers," the Wall Street Journal's Geoffrey Fowler wrote.

Most reviews, while praising the watch's sleek design, highlighted its relatively short battery life - up to 18 hours, according to Apple.

entry.title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
FRANKFURT, April 8 (Reuters) - Apple has made mobile payments look easy, after a decade of mostly failed experiments by banks, telecom operators and retailers to woo consumers away from cards and cash.

Apple Pay has taken the United States by storm since its launch in September, and the company has said it already accounts for around $2 out of every $3 spent using "contactless" payments on the three big U.S. card networks.

Apple Pay allows consumers using new Apple phones, tablets and smartwatches to buy goods by simply holding the device up to readers installed by store merchants.

entry.title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
"The expectation in the industry is that Apple will be launching in new markets in the next quarter or two," he says, citing conversations he has had with credit card companies and major banks in Europe.

Meanwhile, major banks are looking to offer "mobile wallet" payment apps of their own, using some of the same security technology popularized by Apple.

entry.title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
Its potential global customer base is huge: the 800 million Apple users who have already connected credit and debit cards to iTunes accounts.

Credit card companies such as Visa (V.N) and MasterCard (MA.N) - which provided crucial early backing to Apple Pay and are gearing up to support its international expansion - are also looking to hedge their bets and back viable alternatives.

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary: But, said Dr. Steven Zeisel, director of the University of North Carolina's Nutrition Research Institute, "One apple isn't going to be enough to make a difference unless it's part of a healthy food pattern."

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
That's according to proverb-busting research that found daily apple eaters had just as many doctor visits as those who ate fewer or no apples.

About 9 percent of adults studied ate the equivalent of at least one small apple daily.

Apple eaters had more education and were less likely to smoke than apple shunners, and fewer of them were white.

Apple eaters were slightly less likely to use prescription drugs, but the study lacks information on use of over-the-counter medication and alternative medicine.

Apples are a good source of vitamin C; one medium apple has about 100 calories and provides nearly 20 percent of the daily recommended amount of fiber.

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
CHICAGO (AP) - An apple a day doesn't necessarily keep the doctor away.

A preliminary analysis found apple eaters had slightly fewer visits than apple avoiders - those who ate less than one daily or no apples.

entry.title: Apple CEO Tim Cook plans to give away most of his fortune
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO - Apple CEO Tim Cook is joining a long list of magnates promising to give away most of the wealth that they amass during their careers.

Most of Cook's wealth is tied up in an Apple stock grant he received in 2011 when he succeeded Steve Jobs as Apple Inc.'s CEO.

entry.title: Last days of Steve Jobs: Apple CEO invited Tim Cook to watch Denzel Washington movie week before he died
entry.summary:
The book, based on numerous in-depth interviews with Jobs' colleagues, friends and competitors, also allows a glimpse into the Apple CEO's inner sanctum in the final weeks of his life.

In an interesting titbit, the book reveals that Jobs' favorite Beatle was John Lennon, and that he reportedly named his company after Beatles' Apple Corps Record.

The two men bonded over how much they both missed Jobs, and Lasseter confided in the new Apple CEO that he still had his late boss' number on his phone.

In the memoir, which was released this week, Tim Cook did not miss an opportunity to take a swipe at the unauthorized Steve Jobs biography by Walter Isaacson, which debuted just weeks after the Apple co-founder's death.

entry.title: Only 39% of iPhone users interested in Apple Watch: poll

Owners of the iPhone are a particularly important market for Apple as it launches the new watch, which goes on sale April 24.

Social media chatter about the Apple watch was 15% positive and 5% negative in the week following Apple's event, according to an analysis that the firm Networked Insights conducted for Reuters.

entry.title: Only 39% of iPhone users interested in Apple Watch: poll

Among the conversations relating to the Apple watch during the one-week period, 5.8% of the comments showed an intent to purchase, according to Networked Insights, which analyzes tweets, public Facebook posts and other sources.

entry.title: U.S. poll shows 40 per cent of iPhone owners would buy Apple Watch

About 40 percent of adult Apple iPhone owners in the United States are interested in buying the company?s new Apple Watch, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll.

Among the iPhone owners, 39 per cent were interested in purchasing the Apple watch, including 17 per cent describing themselves as very interested.

Apple is not in talks with NBCUniversal, owner of the NBC broadcast network and cable channels like USA and Bravo, because of a falling-out between Apple and NBCUniversal parent company Comcast, the Journal said.

Apple and Comcast were in early-stage discussions last year to offer a streaming-television service that would allow Apple set-top boxes to bypass congestion on the web.

entry.title: Liking Apple too much a big problem for fund managers

Burnham and the 174 fund managers like him who hold large stakes of their diversified portfolios in Apple are pulled in two directions: hoping to prevent an unforeseen drop in Apple shares from upending their portfolios, while also benefiting from a company whose shares are up 12% this year so far.

Other fund managers with large stakes in Apple who aren't selling say that they didn't set out to have an oversized position in the company.

entry.title: Will the Apple Watch finally move the needle in the smartwatch industry? Here's why & why not
entry.summary:
The stakes are big for Apple CEO Tim Cook: the watch is the first brand-new Apple product to be launched without legendary co-founder Steve Jobs.

MORE FEATURES THAN RIVALS: Along with email, texts and phone calls, Apple says its watch will present news, health readings and other notifications in creative ways that can be read at a glance.

Apple is working with outside companies to create more apps; Cook has talked about using the watch as an electronic "key" for hotel doors or even cars.

Apple plans to sell three models, starting at $349, but Piper Jaffray's Gene Munster predicts the average buyer will pay $550 for a watch and extra, interchangeable bands.

entry.title: IPhone 6's popularity drives Apple's China share to record

SEOUL, South Korea (AP) - A consumer survey showed the popularity of the iPhone 6 has driven Apple's market share in China to its highest ever while Samsung has continued to lose ground.

That was a record for Apple in the world's largest smartphone market, but not enough to catch up Chinese maker Xiaomi, which claimed 27.6 percent.

entry.title: "FREAK attack' flaw affected Apple, Android browsers
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Millions of people may have been left vulnerable to hackers while surfing the web on Apple and Google devices, thanks to a newly discovered security flaw known as "FREAK attack."

Apple Inc. and Google Inc. both said Tuesday they have created software updates to fix the "FREAK attack" flaw, which derives its name from an acronym of technical terms.

entry.title: WIRELESS SHOW HIGHLIGHTS: Eyes on Apple, BlackBerry
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - As a major wireless show continues this week in Barcelona, Spain, Apple is highlighting the capabilities of its iPhone cameras with a gallery of photos taken by its users around the world.

The two companies have been fierce rivals, and one research firm said Tuesday that Apple bested Samsung as the world's top smartphone maker in the last three months of 2014.

Apple Inc. isn't at the Mobile World Congress show this week, but is making its presence felt, as new phones are inevitably compared with iPhones.

Apple is turning over a large portion of its home page, along with billboard and print ads in dozens of cities, to photos from its "Shot on iPhone 6" campaign.

entry.title: WIRELESS SHOW HIGHLIGHTS: Eyes on Apple, BlackBerry

Apple's campaign comes as Samsung unveiled new phones with improved photo-taking capabilities.

Apple is featuring 57 photos and three videos from those users at http://apple.com/worldgallery.

entry.title: Apple gives green light to marijuana app, Massroots
